Note: The Heliopolitan priesthood syncretized Atum and Ra, producing Atum-Ra, the first great solar-unity theology of Egypt and all later Egyptian syncretic tendencies (Ptah-Atum-Ra, Amun-Ra, even Aten) descend directly from that Heliopolitan synthesis.
In later Memphite tradition, Ptah is viewed as a proganitor of Atum, creating Atum through the power of speech.
Here Atum is defined as self-created creator god, emerging from Nun and fathering his children—the earliest Egyptian cosmogony. Establishes Heliopolitan theology.
The text depicts him as solar god at sunset, the form into which Ra returns.
The text explains the Ra–Atum cycle—Atum as Ra’s evening manifestation.
The text marks the subsumption of Atum, identifying him as a though-created emanation of Ptah.
Here Shu appears as the primordial god who upholds the sky, separates heaven from earth, and stabilizes cosmic order so the king can ascend among the gods.
He is the cosmic pillar who lifts the sky-cow (Nut) high above the world, physically supporting creation after Ra withdraws from humanity.

She is presented as a primordial goddess of moisture and order who legitimizes the king through her life-giving, purifying power and stands alongside Shu as part of the cosmic pair that stabilizes creation.
The later Memphite tradition morphed Osiris and Ptah. This reinterpretation politically unified northern and southern theologies under the Memphis cult center.
Later tradition venerates Imhotep as "son of Ptah" deifying the famous vizier and more broadly legitimizing priestly/scholarly authority.
The text presents Ptah as a primordial craftsman-creator god who fashions the king’s body, establishes his identity, and empowers him through his role as divine artisan and patron of creation.
Here Ptah is portrayed as the cosmic intellect — the heart and tongue of creation, the origin of Atum, the father of gods, and the ultimate ground of being.

The text contains the earliest direct speeches by Nut and numerous passages where she physically embraces, births, or lifts the king to the heavens. She is presented as both mother and sky — the archetype of cosmic maternity.
Here Nut is central to mythic cosmology — the “Heavenly Cow” who separates earth and sky after humanity’s rebellion against Ra.
Here Geb is established as earth-god, son of Shu and Tefnut, father of Osiris and Isis, holder of kingship and fertility of the soil.
The text shows Geb’s cosmic and dynastic role — heir to Ra’s kingship, anchoring divine authority on earth.
Geb is portrayed as judge and patriarch, conferring legal right of rule to Horus — the archetype for Pharaoh’s earthly kingship.

Thoth and Maat are inseparable in Egyptian thought. Thoth is a scribe of Maat, and he lives in Maat, upholding cosmic order and making sure the Gods and mortals are intelligible between themselves and each other.
Imhotep, as the deified architect, physician, and sage, is often identified as a human embodiment or follower of Thoth.
Earliest full portrayal of Thoth as scribe of the gods, judge, and lord of truth (Maat). He mediates in divine judgment and records cosmic law.
Thoth is presented as divine navigator and magician, ensuring the ordered passage of the sun through night.
Thoth is highlighted as advisor and strategist of Ra—a counselor of divine will.
The text associates him with the creative Logos in the Memphite intellectual system; ties to Ptah’s “heart and tongue.”
He is depicted as guide of the paths of the dead, ensuring correct ritual knowledge.
The text shows his ritual role in solar worship—he maintains order through speech and writing.
Here Thoth's direct theological exposition is presented: god of wisdom, writing, reckoning, and time. Essentially his own “doctrinal” hymn.
In Memphite theology, Nefertum (lotus-born youth) is sometimes child of Ptah and Sekhmet or Hathor. Thus she can appear as his mother in certain variants.
Here Hathor is named as agent of divine punishment in a creation/fall-myth context.
She is named “Mistress of the West” as she welcomes and nurses the king in the underworld.
In Memphite theology, Nefertum (lotus-born youth) is sometimes child of Ptah and Sekhmet or Hathor. Thus she can appear as his mother in certain variants.
Here Sekhmet embodies power and fiery protection. Her connection to Horus and the Eye motif is made clear.
The text defines Sekhmet's duality as bringer of plague and healer — key to later medical-magical theology.
She is presented as guardian of the sun’s passage, defender of the night journey.
Here Sekhmet is integrated into the solar theology — Ra’s flame and executioner of divine will.
The foundational myth describes Sekhmet’s origin as the wrathful Eye of Ra. Her essence is formulated as divine vengeance, solar power, transformation into Hathor.

Secondary Name: Calendars of Lucky and Unlucky Days
Note: The text shows Sekhmet's living presence in daily time, as a dangerous and unpredictable force influencing human fortune.

Ra “established Maat in place of Isfet (chaos)” at creation. Maat is sometimes said to be “daughter of Ra,” or his “consort seated in his boat,” symbolizing that the sun travels within truth. Ra “lives on Maat” — she is the principle that sustains him.
Here Maat is clearly named as the goddess who preserves justice, and the king is placing himself in relation to her throne.
The text links Maat to the underworld journey and shows her being used as a standard (“paths of Maat”) — indicating her cosmic-ordering function.
The Theban doctrine merges Amun and Ra into “the Hidden Sun.” Amun represents invisible divinity, Ra its visible light. By New Kingdom times, they are effectively one god - Amun-Ra.
Here Ra is presented as the supreme solar god, creator of the Ennead, source of life, and model of resurrection.
The text depicts Ra’s nightly voyage through the underworld.
The entire text is a theological catalogue of Ra’s 75 aspects.
The texts centers on Ra’s withdrawal from earth and the creation of heaven.
Ra is presented as moral authority and cosmic judge.
In Memphite theology, Nefertum arises from Osirian fertility.
In Theban religion, Osiris’s renewal parallels Amun’s hidden creative power.
The texts marks the first appearance of Osiris as the resurrected king and ruler of the dead. It Establishes his mythic identity: slain god who grants eternal life.
Here death is first presented as reaching Osiris’s domain.
The text explicitly fuses Ra and Osiris as two aspects of the same cycle — the dying and the resurrected sun.
Here pure Osirian theology is presented: his murder by Seth, restoration by Isis, judgment role, and dominion over the afterlife.
Here Osiris speaks from the underworld as Horus’s divine father; his resurrection legitimizes Horus’s kingship.

Secondary Name: Hymn to Amun-Ra (or Great Hymn to Amun)
Note: The text recognizes Osiris’s resurrection as an act of Amun-Ra’s hidden power.
The text embeds Osiris’s myth inside a Memphite philosophical system: speech and creation.
In Thebes, Isis often assimilated to Mut (“Mother of the God”). Both are maternal aspects of Amun-Ra’s power. Isis absorbs Mut’s queenly symbolism in later hymns.
Earliest source naming Isis as wife of Osiris and mourning goddess who reassembles the dead king. The text establishes her as divine consort and motherly restorer.
Early Middle Kingdom attestation of her protective power for the dead.
The text gives a detailed description of her powers, virtues, and cosmic role beside Osiris.
Here the personality of Isis is defined — intelligent, cunning, maternal.

Secondary Name: Hymn to Amun-Ra (or Great Hymn to Amun)
Note: The text blends Theban and Osirian elements; identifies Isis as universal mother.
Earliest and most formative appearances. Here Seth kills Osiris, but also helps the king ascend the sky in some utterances. Ambivalent — both murderer and protector.
Here Seth is depicted as force of defense, wielding spears of light.
He becomes divine enforcer of destruction — instrument of divine wrath during humanity’s rebellion.
The text portrays Seth as violent, cunning, yet oddly lawful under divine tribunal.
Here he is assimilated to solar vigor; Ra’s violent manifestation.
The text casts Seth as Osiris’s murderer — source of disorder overcome by Osiris’s resurrection.
Here Seth’s violence is framed as an essential tension — his reconciliation is necessary for kingship.

Secondary Name: Calendars of Lucky and Unlucky Days
Note: The text reflects ambivalent superstition — Seth’s day considered dangerous.
The text marks Old Kingdom origin of his identity — embalmer of the king, guardian of the necropolis, guide of the dead. Establishes his role in mummification and resurrection.
Anubis is presented as psychopomp (guide of souls).
The text emphasizes his filial loyalty: embalmer of Osiris, prototype for all later mummification.
Nephthys is introduced as sister of Isis and Osiris, one of the “Two Weepers,” a divine mourner and protector of the dead king.
Here Nephthys is paired with Isis, defining her funerary protective role.
The text reinforces her function as protector of Osiris’s body, embodying lament and restoration.
The text expolores her cosmic dimension—helper in solar renewal.
The text clarifies her family relationships and moral allegiance.
Earliest known chronological record naming Menes as Egypt’s first human ruler. Establishes him as the founder of unified kingship.
By the New Kingdom, Horus merges with Amun and Ra as Amun-Ra-Horakhty — “the Hidden One, the Sun, and the Horizon.” This trinity unites creation, power, and kingship.
Earliest source defining Horus as son and avenger of Osiris, heir to the throne, and embodiment of kingship. The king is Horus on earth.
The text feautures a reflection of Horus’s post-Osirian authority in afterlife navigation.
The text centralizes Horus as the justifier of Osiris—the executor of divine justice and kingship.
The text presents Horus as solar protector and restorer, ensuring cosmic renewal.
Here the solar-syncretic Horus (Ra-Horakhty) is estabilished.
The text displays Horus as intercessor and restorer of cosmic order after divine wrath.

Imhotep was Djoser’s chief architect, vizier, and high priest of Ra at Heliopolis. He designed Djoser’s Step Pyramid and possibly authored ritual and medical texts. Most explicit and verifiable relationship.
Here Imhotep is presented as a divine-healer and patron sage whose presence legitimizes the king’s renewal of ancient cults.
The text portrays Imhotep as a formal state-recognized deity of healing and wisdom, whose cult the king officially endorses in temple and legal terms.
The text identifies Djoser as a historical ruler—first major monarch of Dynasty III—thus verifying his place at the dawn of Egypt’s Old Kingdom.
The text portrays Nefertum as the lotus-born child of the sun, symbol of rebirth and divine fragrance. Establishes his solar and Memphite identity.

Secondary Name: Hymn to Amun-Ra (or Great Hymn to Amun)
Note: The text gives a full theological portrait of Amun as hidden yet omnipresent creator, merciful to petitioners, the solarized “Amun-Ra.” This is the most informative text about his divine character.
The text explains Amun’s hidden essence and his fusion with Ra—defines him as both transcendent and immanent, giving theological meaning to “hiddenness.”
Here Amun is placed within solar cosmology—a guardian and hidden aspect of Ra’s nightly journey.
The text politically marks Amun’s rise as the divine patron of the next royal house.
Here Amun is portrayed as moral protector of the humble, embedding theology in wisdom literature.
The text provides direct insight into his succession and the ethos of 12th-Dynasty kingship: filial duty, vigilance, and divine appointment.
The text establishes Senusret’s reign as fulfillment of prophecy and restoration of order under Amun’s favor.
Here the fullest literary portrait of Senusret I as a living ruler is presented—merciful, wise, divinely protected—showing his administration and personality through narrative.
The text gives his chronological position in Egyptian royal tradition.
The text provides genealogical/historical recognition — confirming his position in the dynastic sequence.
The text establishes her cosmic motherhood and her identity as queen of heaven, paired with Amun-Ra and invoked in resurrection liturgy.
The text estabilised Khonsu is clearly identifiable and given recognizable traits—healing, protection, determining lifespan, lunar cycles.
Here Khonsu is included among gods of the crew of Re, assisting in the transition of the sun through the Duat.
Here Khonsu appears in lists of gods who accompany or embody forms of Re.

Secondary Name: Hymn to Amun-Ra (or Great Hymn to Amun)
Note: The text portrays Khonsu as part of the Theban triad.

Secondary Name: The Great Hymn to the Aten
Note: This theological text was almost certainly authored or supervised by Akhenaten
The text comes after Tutankhamun and Ay and performs a purge of the Amarna legacy. The decree refers to the “time of the heretic king” and the corruption during Akhenaten’s reign.
Tutankhamun appears by throne name Nebkheperure
The text is the major literary monument praising Ramesses II. It mentions him repeatedly by throne name and birth name, and the entire text centers on his exploits.
Here Ramesses II is listed as a legitimate king.
Atum rises from the waters of Nun at the moment of creation.
In Hermopolitan tradition Ra emerges directly from Nun as a child of the primordial waters.
There are two interpreatations: 1) Maat arises after the first differentiation from Nun. 2) Nun is the pre-ordered state; Maat is the ordering principle.
The text depicts Nun as the primordial waters from which the creator emerges.
Here Nun appears as the primeval waters from which Ra emerges in the First Hour.
The text contains indirect but explicit references to Nun as the primordial state before the separation of sky and earth.
Aten begins as an aspect of Ra, and only later (under Akhenaten) becomes elevated into a “supreme” god.

Secondary Name: The Great Hymn to the Aten
Note: The text is the major exposition of theological doctrine of Aten.
The texts share structure, tone, audience, social ethics, and the entire didactic worldview.
Westcar presents Djedefhor (Hardjedef) as a sage in Khufu’s court. This is the only historical-literary attestation of the author outside his Instruction.
The two are a Part of the same Old Kingdom sebayt cluster. They often appear together in manuscripts (“Kagemni + Ptahhotep”).
The Coffin Texts are the direct literary descendants of the Pyramid Texts. Large numbers of Pyramid Text spells were rewritten, expanded, or adapted into Coffin Text spells.
Instruction of Merikare continues the ethical-political maxim tradition shaped by the Old Kingdom sages (Ptahhotep, Kagemni, Hardjedef).
The texts belong to the same scribal medical tradition.
Both are Middle Kingdom royal-sebayt, political-ethical instructions aimed at rulers and successors.
The Coffin Texts preserve, expand, and adapt earlier offering liturgies and mortuary recitations.
The Abydos ritual is specifically tied to Osiris’ cult. The Hymn to Osiris reflects the same core religious focus.
The Book of Two Ways is part of the Coffin Texts.

The Prophecy of Neferti explicitly names Amenemhat I as the divinely destined restorer who will arise after an age of chaos, framing his emergence as the priestly foreknowledge of a savior-king. The Teaching of Amenemhat I completes this ideological arc by presenting the king’s own voice as the source of renewed wisdom.
Both texts construct a vision of societal collapse—famine, inversion of social order, breakdown of Maat.
Same sebayt tradition, deeply concerned with loyalty to the king, social order, and proper conduct toward authority.

Osiris is intimately linked to the Nile’s agricultural cycle (the inundation symbolizes his resurrection). Both hymns express cosmic renewal, fertility, and restoration of life — a shared religious cosmology.
The Book of the Dead directly inherits large portions of Coffin Text material.
Both texts belong to the core sebayt tradition, sharing a didactic worldview centered on ethical conduct, humility, and the maintenance of Maat.
Both texts share the same Middle Kingdom mathematical tradition, problem structures, and scribal computational methods.
Both are major Egyptian medical sources sharing diagnostic modes, pharmaceutical recipes, and the same medical-magical scribal tradition.

The Book of the Dead is fundamentally structured around Osirian resurrection theology — judgment, justification, renewal, protection by Osiris, and identification with him. The hymn expresses the same theological core.
Both texts share the same Middle Kingdom mathematical tradition, problem structures, and scribal computational methods.

Both texts are New Kingdom underworld books that map Re’s nightly passage through the Duat using parallel hour-by-hour structures, shared cosmography, and the same solar–Osirian resurrection theology.

Primary Name: Hymn to Amun-Ra (or Great Hymn to Amun)
Secondary Name: The Great Hymn to the Aten
Note: Both are monumental cosmic hymns praising a supreme solar creator-god.
The texts share a cosmic-structural focus on the arrangement of the universe, divine separation, and the cosmic geography between sky, earth, and netherworld.

Primary Name: The Great Hymn to the Aten
Note: Both texts belong to the formal hymn genre: poetic theological praise, divine epithets, cosmic ordering, creation motifs, and liturgical function.

Both texts are New Kingdom underworld books that depict Re’s nightly passage through the Duat through complementary cosmographies and share the same solar–Osirian resurrection theology, even though the Book of the Earth is not organized into hour-by-hour divisions like the Book of Gates.
Both are royal legal-administrative command texts regulating officials and asserting the king’s legal authority.
Both are monumental royal victory inscriptions, narrating military success, asserting kingship, and projecting state power.

The Book of the Earth and the Book of Caverns are closely related late New Kingdom underworld books that present complementary cosmographies focused on Osiris’ hidden body, the deep regions of the Duat, and the solar–Osirian cycle of death and regeneration.

Both are narrative compositions built around familial betrayal, divine justice, and mythic prototypes of kingship. The story of Bata and Anpu explicitly echoes the Osiris–Horus–Seth mythic pattern (murder, exile, vindication, restoration).
Both texts belong to the core sebayt tradition, sharing a didactic worldview centered on ethical conduct, humility, and the maintenance of Maat.
